metadata.name: Periodic Table – First 70 Elements
metadata.description: Atomic number, symbol, and core properties for the first 70 elements of the periodic table.

schema.label: Atomic Number
schema.description: Number of protons in the nucleus. Defines the element.

schema.label: Symbol
schema.description: Standard one- or two-letter chemical symbol (e.g., H, He, Li).

schema.label: Element Name
schema.description: Official English name of the element.

schema.label: Atomic Mass
schema.description: Standard atomic weight (average mass of naturally occurring isotopes).

schema.label: Group
schema.description: Vertical column number in the periodic table (1–18).

schema.label: Period
schema.description: Horizontal row number in the periodic table.

schema.label: Category
schema.description: Chemical family classification of the element.

values.post-transition-metal: Metals after transition metals in the p-block.

schema.label: State at STP
schema.description: Physical state at standard temperature and pressure (0°C, 1 atm).

schema.label: Common Uses
schema.description: Typical real-world applications of the element.

schema.label: Name Origin
schema.description: Origin or meaning behind the element’s name.

schema.label: Discovered
schema.description: Year the element was discovered or first recognized. 0 - antiquity.

schema.label: Discovered By
schema.description: Person or people credited with the discovery.

schema.label: Notes
schema.description: Optional study notes, mnemonics, or important facts.

schema.label: Electron Configuration
schema.description: Electron configuration in noble-gas shorthand (e.g., [He] 2s2 2p2). Use standard spectroscopic notation.

schema.label: Irregular Electron Configuration
schema.description: True if the ground-state electron configuration is a well-known exception to the simple Aufbau filling order (commonly in d/f blocks, e.g., Cr, Cu).

entries.name: Hydrogen
notes: Most abundant element in the universe

entries.name: Helium
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'Helios', meaning 'Sun', because it was first detected in the solar spectrum.

entries.name: Lithium
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'lithos', meaning 'stone', because it was discovered in minerals.
notes: Stored under oil to prevent reaction

entries.name: Sodium
entries.nameOrigin: From English 'soda'; symbol Na from Latin 'natrium'.

entries.name: Magnesium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after Magnesia region in Greece.

entries.name: Aluminum
notes: Most abundant metal in Earth's crust

entries.name: Silicon
notes: Second most abundant element in Earth's crust

entries.name: Argon
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'argos' meaning inactive or lazy.
notes: Third most abundant gas in air

entries.name: Potassium
entries.nameOrigin: From English 'potash'; symbol K from Latin 'kalium'.

entries.name: Scandium
notes: Often found with rare earth elements

entries.name: Titanium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after the Titans of Greek mythology.

entries.name: Vanadium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after Vanadis, a Norse goddess.

entries.name: Manganese
entries.nameOrigin: From Latin 'magnes', referring to magnetic minerals.

entries.name: Iron
entries.nameOrigin: From Old English 'iren'; symbol Fe from Latin 'ferrum'.

entries.name: Copper
commonUses: Alloys such as brass and bronze

entries.name: Arsenic
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'arsenikon', referring to yellow arsenic compounds.

entries.name: Selenium
notes: Can be toxic at high doses

entries.name: Krypton
notes: Emits whitish light in discharge tubes

entries.name: Strontium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after Strontian, a village in Scotland.

entries.name: Yttrium
notes: Often grouped with rare earth elements

entries.name: Niobium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after Niobe from Greek mythology.

entries.name: Technetium
notes: Tc-99m is widely used in diagnostics

entries.name: Ruthenium
entries.nameOrigin: From 'Ruthenia', a Latin term for Russia.

entries.name: Silver
entries.nameOrigin: From Old English 'seolfor'; symbol from Latin 'argentum'.
notes: Best electrical conductor of all metals

entries.name: Cadmium
notes: Often obtained as a zinc refining by-product

entries.name: Tin
entries.nameOrigin: From Old English 'tin'; symbol from Latin 'stannum'.
notes: Can undergo 'tin pest' at low temperatures

entries.name: Cesium
notes: Defines the SI second in Cs-133 clocks

entries.name: Barium
notes: Elemental barium is not found free in nature

entries.name: Lanthanum
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'lanthanein', meaning to lie hidden.

entries.name: Cerium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after the dwarf planet Ceres.

entries.name: Praseodymium
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek words meaning green twin.
notes: Used with neodymium in strong magnets

entries.name: Neodymium
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek words meaning new twin.

entries.name: Promethium
entries.nameOrigin: Named after Prometheus from Greek mythology.

entries.name: Europium
notes: Important in display and lighting phosphors

entries.name: Dysprosium
entries.nameOrigin: From Greek 'dysprositos', meaning hard to get.

entries.name: Holmium
notes: Used in some medical and industrial lasers

entries.name: Erbium
notes: Gives pink color to some glasses

entries.name: Thulium
entries.nameOrigin: From Thule, an ancient name for northern lands.
notes: One of the least abundant lanthanides
Tm-170 used as a radiation source

entries.name: Ytterbium
notes: Can improve grain refinement in alloys
